maml:description.maml:para: Gets user profile objects from local or remote systems.
The Get-UserProfile cmdlet retrieves the specified user profile and its properties. If you do not specify a profile name, the cmdlet returns a list of all user profiles.
Specifies a path to one or more user profiles. Wildcards are permitted.
Gets only the user profiles that has been loaded before the specified date and time. Enter a DateTime object, such as the one returned by the Get-Date cmdlet.
Specifies the status of the user profiles being enumerated.
Specifies whether the returned user profiles should include currently loaded ones (or not)
Specifies whether the returned user profiles should include roaming profiles (or not)
Specifies whether the returned user profiles should include these that are owned by a special system service.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies profile owner Security ID (SID). Wildcards are permitted.
Gets only the user profiles that has been loaded before the specified date and time. Enter a DateTime object, such as the one returned by the Get-Date cmdlet.
Specifies the status of the user profiles being enumerated.
Specifies whether the returned user profiles should include currently loaded ones (or not)
Specifies whether the returned user profiles should include roaming profiles (or not)

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies a path to one or more user profiles. Wildcards are permitted.
Specifies profile owner Security ID (SID). Wildcards are permitted.
Specifies the status of the user profiles being enumerated.
Specifies whether the returned user profiles should include currently loaded ones (or not)
Specifies whether the returned user profiles should include roaming profiles (or not)

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Gets only the user profiles that has been loaded before the specified date and time. Enter a DateTime object, such as the one returned by the Get-Date cmdlet.
User Profile CIM object

maml:alert.maml:para: The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example receives all user profiles from local computer
This example retreives all user profiles that are not used for 3 months (90 days)
This example retrieves the AD user Joe's profile.
This example retrieves local user's profile.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes specified user profiles.
The Remove-UserProfile cmdlet removes specified user profiles from the system.
Specifies a path to one or more user profiles. Wildcards are permitted.
Gets only the user profiles that has been loaded before the specified date and time. Enter a DateTime object, such as the one returned by the Get-Date cmdlet.
Specifies the status of the user profiles being enumerated.
Specifies whether the returned user profiles should include currently loaded ones (or not)
Specifies whether the returned user profiles should include roaming profiles (or not)
Specifies whether the returned user profiles should include these that are owned by a special system service.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies that the cmdlet should output an object representing a user profile. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies profile owner Security ID (SID). Wildcards are permitted.
Gets only the user profiles that has been loaded before the specified date and time. Enter a DateTime object, such as the one returned by the Get-Date cmdlet.

Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the user profile to remove. Enter a User Profile CIM object, which you can get by using the Get-UserProfile cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example removes profile for user account Joe
This example removes all user profiles which are corrupt and cannot be loaded.
This example finds all user profiles that are not used for 3 moths (90 days) and removes them.
This example removes all local copies of roaming user profiles that are not currently loaded.

maml:description.maml:para: Changes user profile owner.
The Set-ProfileOwner cmdlet replaces owner of one or more user profiles.
Specifies a path to one or more user profiles. Wildcards are permitted.
Specifies new owner's Security ID (SID) for user profile.
Specifies, whether do you want to overwrite new owner's existing profile.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies that the cmdlet should output an object representing a user profile. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the user profile to process. Enter a User Profile CIM object, which you can get by using the Get-UserProfile cmdlet.
Specifies new owner's Security ID (SID) for user profile.
Specifies, whether do you want to overwrite new owner's existing profile.

Specifies that the cmdlet should output an object representing a user profile. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies a path to one or more user profiles. Wildcards are permitted.
User Profile CIM object

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $oldOwner = Get-AdUser John $newOwner = Get-AdUser Joe Get-UserProfile -SID $oldOwner.SID | Set-ProfileOwner -SID $newOwner.SID

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example takes user profile of John and replaces the owner with user Joe.
